Case Study: The Nhlungwane Community Water Supply Project
The Nhlungwane project is situated in southern KwaZulu-Natal. The community has approximately 227 households with a population of 1,100. With the assistance of the Mvula Trust, a water project was established and completed in 1997. Since then, the project has been functioning without interruption, and with very high recovery of operating costs. The income, collected from household fees of US$0.7 per month, exceeds the expenses of the water scheme, and this has left the community with a bank balance of over US$1,100 (in early 2002). The scheme uses borehole water, pumped by a diesel-powered pump to an elevated reservoir and then fed by gravity to 41 public tapstands. The tapstands have their own wardens, who are all women (often referred to as `nompompis'). These wardens offer their services voluntarily and the responsibility rotates through the households adjacent to the tapstand. Each warden keeps the key for the tapstand, and every day at a specified time the warden opens the tapstand for the people to come and collect water. The wardens also record the monthly payments of the households around their tapstand.
Success factors
· Nhlungwane village is an inherently cohesive community, in which the Mvula Trust's demand-responsive approach has helped engender a strong sense of ownership and responsibility for the water scheme. · The Village Water Committee has good working relationships with traditional authority structures, and ensures open and regular communication with the villagers through community meetings. · The project was initiated, and is run, by a number of dynamic individuals, who were influential in creating a momentum for the water project among the community members. · The Village Water Committee has an underpinning of community women's organisations, which have been active in the village for decades already.

5  Case Study: The Rural Schools Sanitation Programme
Between1997and2002,theMvulaTrustimplementedtheRuralSchoolsSanitationProgrammewithfundingfromtheEuropeanUnion. In more than 150 schools, ventilated improved pit (VIP) latrines were constructed, and proper health and hygiene training and awareness raising were carried out. The schools were requested to contribute 10% of the construction costs, in order to stimulate a sense of ownership of the project and to ensure the accountability of the project committees to parents. Also, the schools were asked to form clusters of at least five neighbouring schools which all needed sanitation. This cluster approach had two main advantages. Firstly, unit costs (of administration, for example) were lowered as economies of scale became available. Secondly, schools could help each other maintain momentum through peer pressure. A disadvantage was the frustration that was felt by some schools as other schools in their clusters failed to keep to deadlines and agreements, causing delays for all schools in these clusters.

Through promoting the use of local professionals and their skills, working with the government to achieve replication and the scaling up of improved approaches to rural development, and by engaging constructively to influence policy more effectively, the Mvula Trust is making an impact beyond its financial strength. Focus for the future
The Mvula Trust sees four major challenges for the coming years: · To ensure that poor rural communities benefit from the free basic water policy as soon as possible, and that the subsidy is provided in as cost effective a manner as possible, and is sustained. · To expand its rural sanitation programme, giving it equal importance with the water supply programme, and to ensure that the approach used is in line with the development principles of national policy. · To develop water services in a more holistic way, by implementing them in line with national government's Integrated Sustainable Rural Development Strategy. · To maintain its own intellectual independence despite its financial reliance on project income rather than core income. In the light of these challenges, the Mvula Trust intends to step outside the boundaries of water and sanitation provision, to explore related issues such as water resource management, rural livelihoods and local economic development related to access to potable waterandsanitation.

NGOs can help governments through demonstrating good practice, providing services, carrying out evaluations and pioneering new policies. On the other hand it is important for NGOs to maintain organisational and political independence from government, in order to retain credibility at community level and act effectively as advocates for the poor. A large-scale, organisationally and politically independent NGO, structured with constructive linkages to government's overall policy objectives, can play a significant role in speeding up delivery to achieve national sector objectives. Independent delivery mechanisms can overcome bureaucratic hurdles and provide an external benchmark for government's own performance.
